properties.name: Advice
properties.location: the Kiewa River to Mongans Bridge
properties.webBody:
This is a Final Minor Flood Warning for the Kiewa River to Mongans Bridge. 

MINOR FLOODING POSSIBLE AT BANDIANA FROM TUESDAY AFTERNOON

River levels have risen along the Kiewa River in response to recent rainfall. Minor flooding may develop at Bandiana from Tuesday afternoon.

Rainfall has now eased across the Kiewa River catchment. In the 24 hours to 12:00 pm Tuesday rainfall totals up to 10 mm have been recorded, and up to 5 mm are forecast for the remainder of Tuesday. Higher falls, including snow, about elevated areas are possible.

Kiewa River to Mongans Bridge:
The Kiewa River at Mongans Bridge is currently at 1.57 metres and falling slowly. River levels remain elevated along the Kiewa River to Mongans Bridge during Tuesday.

The threat of flooding is reduced. Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and beware of hazards remaining in the warning area.
What you should do:

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.

If your home or business has been flooded:
  • Check for building damage before you enter.
  • Have all electrical and gas equipment professionally tested before use.
  • Clean and dry out the building as soon as possible.

Call Triple Zero (000) in a life threatening emergency. For emergency assistance from the SES call 132 500.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Low lying caravan parks and camping grounds may be flooded.
  • River heights in your area are likely to remain high.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

This will be the last warning for this flood. 

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

cap.senderName: Department of Environment, Land, Water & Planning

properties.name: Community Information
properties.location: Coast Marlo to the Victoria-New South Wales Border
properties.webBody:
This message is being issued for coastal water from Marlo to the Victoria-New South Wales Border.  

  • The Blue Green Algae bloom currently affecting parts of the Gippsland Lakes and Ninety Mile Beach has now been detected in the ocean along parts of the Gippsland coast.
  • Movement of the bloom is being influenced by the weather and tidal system.  
Do not eat prawns from affected waters.

These prawns may have come from the Gippsland Lakes and Ninety Mile Beach area and may contain toxins from the algae.

Ingesting these toxins can lead to serious illness.

Avoid contact with ocean water where algae is visible.
What you should do:
  • Visit betterhealth.vic.gov.au for more information. 

This message was issued by Department of Environment, Land, Water & Planning.

The next update is expected by 10/06/2022 04:20 pm or as the situation changes.

Information about blue green algae:
  • For information on blue green algae visit: www2.health.vic.gov.au/public-health/water/blue-green-algae-cyanobac teria.
Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au.
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app.
  • Facebook or Twitter.
  • Tune into ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for the Kiewa River at Bandiana.

MINOR FLOODING POSSIBLE AT BANDIANA FROM TUESDAY AFTERNOON

River levels have risen along the Kiewa River in response to recent rainfall. Minor flooding may develop at Bandiana from Tuesday afternoon.

Rainfall has now eased across the Kiewa River catchment. In the 24 hours to 12:00 pm Tuesday rainfall totals up to 10 mm have been recorded, and up to 5 mm are forecast for the remainder of Tuesday. Higher falls, including snow, about elevated areas are possible.

Kiewa River downstream of Mongans Bridge:
Minor flooding may develop along the Kiewa River downstream of Mongans Bridge.

The Kiewa River at Kiewa (Main Stream) is currently peaking around 2.95 metres (below the minor flood level 3.30 m). The Kiewa River at Kiewa (Main Stream) is expected to remain below the minor flood level (3.30 m) during Tuesday.

The Kiewa River at Bandiana is currently at 2.64 metres and steady. The Kiewa River at Bandiana may reach the minor flood level (2.80 m) Tuesday afternoon.

Kiewa River to Mongans Bridge:
The Kiewa River at Mongans Bridge is currently at 1.57 metres and falling slowly. River levels remain elevated along the Kiewa River to Mongans Bridge during Tuesday.

Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Farmers should consider moving livestock and machinery to higher ground.
  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
Impacts in your area: 

  • Low Lying caravan parks and camping grounds may be flooded.
  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 08/06/2022 01:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

cap.senderName: Department of Environment, Land, Water & Planning

properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This message is being issued for water quality at Curdies River.

  • High levels of blue green algae have been detected in the Curdies River, from Boggy Creek Rd (north) to Curdies River inlet (south). 
  • The algal bloom is expected to remain until there is significant rainfall to flush the river or cooler conditions slow the algae.  
  • Regular testing is being conducted to identify new outbreaks or changes that might indicate improved water quality.  
  • This notification will be reviewed weekly and updated as the situation changes. 
  • Warning signs have been installed along the river. 
You should avoid direct contact with affected water in Curdies River and Curdies Inlet.

Do not swim in affected areas or use water for cooking, drinking, washing or showering. Boiling the water will not make it safe. 
What you should do:
  • Visit https://www.health.vic.gov.au/water/health-effects-of-blue-green-algae for more information. 
  • Observe information signs posted at the river.

Protect your health:
  • Direct contact with water affected by blue green algae can cause skin irritation, sore eyes, ears and nose. If swallowed it can cause cramps, nausea and vomiting. 
  • If you do come into contact with affected water, wash your skin immediately in clean cool water. 
  • Boiling affected water does not make it safe to drink. Boiling water bursts the blue green algae cells and releases toxins into the water making it more likely that you will experience symptoms. 
  • If you are experiencing any health issues after contact with affected water seek medical advice from your local doctor or Nurse-On-Call on 1300 60 60 24.

Protect your pets:
  • Pet owners should prevent pets from drinking or having direct contact with contaminated water. 

Farming information: 
  • Stock can be poisoned if they drink blue green algae contaminated water. 
  • Farmers are advised to access alternative stock water supplies if they suspect blue green algal contamination. 
  • Pastures that have been irrigated using affected water should not be grazed for at least seven days.  
  • If blue green algae poisoning is suspected in livestock, or a number of livestock die suddenly, contact your local vet or Agriculture Victoria on 136 186.
Impacts in your area:
  • The water is green as a result of the algae bloom.

Boating and fishing:
  • Boating and fishing is still allowed in these areas, however care needs to be taken.
  • Do not eat mussels, crayfish or yabbies caught from the affected area. 
  • If you see fish that are dead, dying or swimming erratically do not touch or eat them. 

This message was issued by Department of Environment, Land, Water & Planning.

The next update is expected by 01/07/2022 05:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Information about blue green algae:
  • For information on blue green algae visit: www2.health.vic.gov.au/public-health/water/blue-green-algae-cyanobac teria.
  • For information on blue green algae and stock visit: http://agriculture.vic.gov.au/agriculture/pests-diseases-and-weeds/animal-diseases/beef-and-dairy-cows/blue-green-algal -poisoning-of-stock.
  • For information on blue green algae and irrigation visit: http://agriculture.vic.gov.au/agriculture/farm-management/soil-and-water/irrigation/blue-green-algae-and-irrigation-water.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au.
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app.
  • Facebook or Twitter.
  • Tune into ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

cap.senderName: Department of Environment, Land, Water & Planning

properties.name: Community Information
properties.location: Gippsland Lakes and the Gippsland Coast from McLoughlins Beach to Marlo
properties.webBody:
This message is being issued for water in the Gippsland Lakes and the Ninety Mile Beach from McLoughlins Beach to Marlo.

  • Blue Green Algae is currently affecting parts of the Gippsland Lakes and Ninety Mile Beach.
  • The only site in the Gippsland Lakes area that is safe for human contact is Lake Wellington. 
  • Avoid contact with water and do not let your pet swim in other areas of the Gippsland Lakes system.
  • The bloom has now been detected in the ocean along parts of the Gippsland coast, where its movement is being influenced by the weather and tidal system. 
  • Algae may be more visible at low tide.
  • Avoid contact with ocean water where algae is visible.
  • Do not eat shellfish, crustaceans (e.g. prawns, bugs, crabs) or pilchards from affected waters. 
  • Finfish caught in from affected areas should be rinsed thoroughly in fresh water and the guts and gills removed before cooking or freezing.
  • Ingesting these toxins can lead to serious illness. Cooking or freezing does not destroy the toxins
  • Do not swim in affected areas or use water for cooking, drinking, washing or showering. Boiling the water will not make it safe. 
  • Avoid contact with ocean water where algae is visible.
What you should do:
  • Visit betterhealth.vic.gov.au for more information. 
Protect your health:
  • Direct contact with water affected by blue green algae can cause skin irritation, sore eyes, ears and nose. If swallowed it can cause cramps, nausea and vomiting. 
  • If you do come into contact with affected water, wash your skin immediately in clean cool water. 
  • Boiling affected water does not make it safe to drink. Boiling water bursts the blue green algae cells and releases toxins into the water making it more likely that you will experience symptoms. 
  • If you are experiencing any health issues after contact with affected water seek medical advice from your local doctor or Nurse-On-Call on 1300 60 60 24.

Protect your pets:
  • Pet owners should prevent pets from drinking or having direct contact with contaminated water. 
Boating and fishing:
  • Boating and fishing is still allowed in these areas, however care needs to be taken.
This message was issued by Department of Environment, Land, Water & Planning.

The next update is expected by 10/06/2022 05:20 pm or as the situation changes.

Information about blue green algae:
  • For information on blue green algae visit: www.betterhealth.vic.gov.au/harmful-algal-blooms 
Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au.
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app.
  • Facebook or Twitter.
  • Tune into ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

- Do not eat shellfish, crustaceans (e.g. prawns, bugs, crabs) or pilchards from affected waters.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This is a Final Minor Flood Warning for the Seven and Castle Creeks. 

  • Rainfall has now eased across the Seven Creeks catchment and minor flooding is no longer expected to develop at Euroa

Seven Creeks to Euroa:

Flooding is no longer expected to develop in the Seven Creeks to Euroa.

The Seven Creeks at Euroa peaked below the minor flood level and is currently at 2.33 metres and falling.  The Seven Creeks at Euroa is expected to remain below the minor flood level (2.50 m) during Tuesday
The threat of flooding is reduced. Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and beware of hazards remaining in the warning area.
What you should do:

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.

If your home or business has been flooded:
  • Check for building damage before you enter.
  • Have all electrical and gas equipment professionally tested before use.
  • Clean and dry out the building as soon as possible.

Call Triple Zero (000) in a life threatening emergency. For emergency assistance from the SES call 132 500.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Damage to roads and buildings caused by flooding may still exist in your area. 
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

This will be the last warning for this flood. 

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: the King River at Docker Road
properties.webBody:
MINOR FLOODING IS OCCURRING AT DOCKER ROAD BRIDGE

Minor flooding is occurring along the King River at Docker Rd Bridge and is expected to continue for the remainder of Tuesday.

Rainfall has eased across the King River catchment. Since 9:00 am Tuesday rainfall totals of less than 5 mm have been recorded. No significant rainfall is forecast for the remainder of Tuesday.

King River:
Minor flooding is occurring along the King River downstream of Lake William Hovell.

The King River downstream of Lake William Hovell is currently at 1.65 metres and falling. The King River downstream of Lake William Hovell is expected to remain below the minor flood level (1.80 m) during Tuesday.

The King River at Docker Rd Bridge is currently peaking at around 3.77 metres, with minor flooding and steady. 

The King River at Docker Rd Bridge is expected to remain above the minor flood level (3.70 m) Tuesday afternoon. 

The river level is likely to fall below the minor flood level (3.70 m) Tuesday evening.

Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Farmers should consider moving livestock and machinery to higher ground.
  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Contact family members and neighbours to ensure they are aware of the situation.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Low Lying caravan parks and camping grounds may be flooded.
  • Local roads may be closed and low bridges may be underwater.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 08/06/2022 11:00 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

cap.senderName: Department of Environment, Land, Water & Planning

properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This message is being issued for water quality at Lake Bolac.

  • High levels of blue green algae have been detected in the lake. 
  • The algal bloom is expected to remain until there is significant rainfall to flush the lake or cooler conditions slow the algae. 
  • Regular testing is being conducted to identify new outbreaks or changes that might indicate improved water quality. 
  • This notification will be reviewed weekly and updated as the situation changes. 
Warning signs have been installed at the lake. 

You should avoid direct contact with affected water in Lake Bolac. 

Do not swim in affected areas or use water for cooking, drinking, washing or showering. Boiling the water will not make it safe. 
What you should do:
  • Visit Parks Victoria website for more information. 
  • Observe information signs posted at the Lake Bolac.
Protect your health:
  • Direct contact with water affected by blue green algae can cause skin irritation, sore eyes, ears and nose. If swallowed it can cause cramps, nausea and vomiting. 
  • If you do come into contact with affected water, wash your skin immediately in clean cool water. 
  • Boiling affected water does not make it safe to drink. Boiling water bursts the blue green algae cells and releases toxins into the water making it more likely that you will experience symptoms. 
  • If you are experiencing any health issues after contact with affected water seek medical advice from your local doctor or Nurse-On-Call on 1300 60 60 24.
Protect your pets:
  • Pet owners should prevent pets from drinking or having direct contact with contaminated water. 
Agriculture information: 
  • Irrigation water contaminated with blue green algae should not be spray irrigated on vegetables and fruit, or come in contact with plants being grown for food during processing and packing. 
  • Fruit and vegetables grown in the affected areas are safe to consume if farmers follow recommendations regarding blue green algae.
Impacts in your area:
  • The water is green as a result of the algae bloom.

Boating and fishing:
  • Boating and fishing is still allowed in these areas, however care needs to be taken.
  • Fish caught from affected areas should be rinsed and cleaned thoroughly in fresh water, and internal organs removed from the fish and discarded before eating. 
  • Do not eat mussels, crayfish or yabbies caught from the affected area. 

This message was issued by Department of Environment, Land, Water & Planning.

The next update is expected by 01/07/2022 11:20 am or as the situation changes.

Information about blue green algae:
  • For information on blue green algae visit: www2.health.vic.gov.au/public-health/water/blue-green-algae-cyanobac teria.
  • For information on blue green algae and stock visit: http://agriculture.vic.gov.au/agriculture/pests-diseases-and-weeds/animal-diseases/beef-and-dairy-cows/blue-green-algal -poisoning-of-stock.
  • FOr information on blue green algae and irrigation visit: http://agriculture.vic.gov.au/agriculture/farm-management/soil-and-water/irrigation/blue-green-algae-and-irrigation-water.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au.
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app.
  • Facebook or Twitter.
  • Tune into ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
properties.text:
COMMUNITY INFORMATION - BLUE GREEN ALGAE
Incident Location: Lake Bolac
Issue Date: Monday 06 June 2022, 11:12 am
Next Update: Friday 01 July 2022, 11:20 am

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/20865/moreinfo

This message is being issued for water quality at Lake Bolac. 

- High levels of blue green algae have been detected in the lake. 
- The algal bloom is expected to remain until there is significant rainfall to flush the lake or cooler conditions slow the algae. 
- Regular testing is being conducted to identify new outbreaks or changes that might indicate improved water quality. 
- This notification will be reviewed weekly and updated as the situation changes.  


Warning signs have been installed at the lake. 

You should avoid direct contact with affected water in Lake Bolac. 

Do not swim in affected areas or use water for cooking, drinking, washing or showering. Boiling the water will not make it safe.
